description: Contentious battles among media owners, content creators, advertisers, and advocates play an important role in influencing the structure and content of contemporary communications -- broadcasting, cable T.V., and now broadband. These struggles take place across a spectrum of sites in Washington, from the halls and hearing rooms of Congress, to regulatory agencies such as the Federal Communications Commission to the plush offices of K Street lobbying firms. Through a series of case studies and guest speakers, we will examine a variety of policy and programming issues,as well as political, economic, and social forces, that are having a major impact on the media landscape. Topics to be covered will include: minority and female media ownership, public interest content and news programming, broadband access, interactive advertising, public media, newspaper ownership, and digital music distribution.
